Chapter VI

Later, Raskolnikov remembered the scene like this.

The noise behind the door got louder, and then the door opened a little.

“What is it?” Porfiry Petrovitch shouted, annoyed. “I gave orders…”

At first, no one answered, but it was clear that there were several people at the door, and they were pushing someone back.

“What is it?” Porfiry Petrovitch asked again, looking uneasy.

“The prisoner Nikolay has been brought,” someone said.

“He is not wanted! Take him away! Let him wait! What’s he doing here? This is so wrong!” Porfiry yelled as he rushed to the door.

“But he…” the same voice started to say, then stopped.

In just a couple of seconds, there was a struggle, then someone pushed hard, and a very pale man walked into the room.

This man looked strange at first. He stared straight ahead as if he couldn’t see anything. His eyes had a determined look, but his face was very pale, like he was being taken to his execution. His white lips were slightly twitching.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov recalls the chaotic moment when the prisoner Nikolay is unexpectedly brought into the room, causing confusion and annoyance among the officials.
